subject: RE: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
msgSnippet: ... I d like to argue against this.  Having many assertions per test makes it more difficult to see where the problem is.  With simple, well name tests it is
messageBody:
Di Iorio, Matthew (ISS Atlanta) wrote:
> As an aside, we count asserts instead of tests becase it's a
> finer grained metric. Right now we only have 8 functional
> test methods, but 170 assertions. When we add to a functional
> test we don't create a new test method, we add some more
> assertions to an already existing test. It would be harder to
> see progress if we tracked test cases.

I'd like to argue against this. Having many assertions per test
makes it more difficult to see where the problem is. With
simple, well name tests it is often enough to see the name and
know exactly where to look in your code. With long complicated
tests, you'll probably have to read the *test* again before you
even start looking in the code. I also often write several
related tests that build on each other -- if the first fails I
expect the others in the group to fail too. If only the first
fails, it is a hint that there may be a problem with that test.

I just don't see a good reason to count asserts. There's no
magic ratio of asserts to tests that is better than another. As
for impressing the boss with bigger numbers, that's not a good
reason to incorporate it into the framework :-).

-- Andrew
